relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
we're visiting with Georgia Kelly, the Executive Director of the Praxis Peace Institute.
you're an expert on the Mondragon Cooperative System.
amazing community and corporate structure over in the Basque region of Spain.
She has produced and directed several multi-day conferences in Europe and the United States.
continues to create educational programs for Praxis.
leading seminars and tours abroad in places like Italy, Cuba, Croatia, and Spain.

one of the big arms of the Mondragon system has to do with food and agriculture.
they always had fewer far fewer agricultural cooperatives because it's a hilly terrain.
we try to tailor the particular seminar to what our group of people going that year want to learn about.
One thing that they do have is a large supermarket chain called arosky. And they are all over Spain.
they started converting the arosky supermarkets in the vast region... to worker owned.
it's my opinion that one of the top 10 or 12 most important issues we have in front of us to take on and tackle and transform is food system related.
it's as if you're in this gourmet artisan, you know, all these fresh foods produce wonderful olives, olive oil, fresh baked breads.
which is quite a contrast from most of what we see here in the United States.

that isn't the kind of person who thrives in a cooperative community.
what they always tell us when we go for our seminar is that you have to be mature to be in a cooperative.
they work on consensus.
if they have to make a decision in a certain amount of time, they will go with a simple majority.
the cooperatives in the US that began with that idea that we will be consensus driven will always be a hundred percent agreement.
I never referred to as the tyranny of the minority.
Democratic process means people have different opinions, different ideas they bring to the fore and share.
that's a sense of maturity and not being ego driven.

he just forged their names, took the papers to the government and established the bank.

When I lived in Mill Valley, he lived just behind me on the hill.
sometimes we would just talk from our backyards.
we got together, probably at least three times a week, either for lunch or coffee or tea.
we would talk about the books he was reading to prepare for writing that book.
So I started reading all the same books so we could talk about them.
I think Bernard was like a mentor.

the creation of patriarchy by Gerta Lerner, which is a profound book.
